When you enter the city you can see its newest landmark - the bridge of Europe, also called, \"the harp of Bruck\". But what is the most famous building of the city?
The main square was named after which person?

The city has a tradition of naming streets, places, parks and even a tree after famous historical people from different areas. Artists, politicians, scientists and other famous peoples names can be seen throughout the city. Often a short biography is added to the street signs. But who was the main square named after?
Bertha von Suttner (Nobel peace price winner)
Theodor Körner (advocate for easy access to education)
Koloman Wallisch (key member of resistance against Austrias catholic-fascist regime)
Margarete Schütte-Lihotzky (iconic architect of the era of "red Vienna")
When was the great city fire?

Some time ago a fire destroyed or partly destroyed 164 of 166 buildings in the city. There is a saga that a local clown tried to inform the citizen about the fire but was not seriously by them. As a result the city burned to the ground. To remember that saga there is an annual street-art festival called \"Murenschalk\" that\'s named after the saga. But in what year did the fire happen?
What sites are part of the main square?

The main square of bruck is one of the biggest inner-city squares of Austria. So... there\'s quite a bit of space and there are same interesting spots on the main square and surrounding it. But Bruck has quite a lot of sites to offer considering it\'s quite a small town in Austria. Which of the sites are at the main square?
What was the name of the city that fusioned with Bruck in 2015?

Bruck an der Mur is in the heart of the upper styrian steel industry region. With the crisis of this formerly state-owned insustry in the 1980s the pupulation went down year over year from over 18.000 in the early 1970s to around 13.000 in 2014. With the fusion of Bruck with one of its neighbor cities in 2015 the popualation went up again to over 15.000 citizens. With what city did Bruck fusion?

Which of these rivers flow through the city?

The origin of the city\'s name comes from a bridge crossing the river Mur. Bridges and Rivers were of significent importance for the city and its development for centuries. The city\'s coat of arms contributes this by showing a bridge and a river. Which of these rivers run through Bruck an der Mur?
